These are the methods by which the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to pray the night prayer and Witr. Other types can be added to them, by decreasing from each type of the mentioned methods whatever Rak'ahs one wishes, and it is even permissible for him to restrict himself to one Rak'ah only, due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "So whoever wishes, let him perform Witr with five; whoever wishes, let him perform Witr with three; and whoever wishes, let him perform Witr with one," which has passed. This Hadith is a text regarding the permissibility of performing Witr with these three mentioned types, even if practicing them was not authentically reported from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him; rather, what was authentic from the Hadith of Aisha is that he, peace and blessings be upon him, did not use to perform Witr with less than seven, as preceded there. [107]

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: So these five and three, if he wishes, he can pray them with one sitting and one Tasleem as in the second type. And if he wishes, he can pray them with a sitting between every two Rak'ahs without Tasleem as in the fourth type. And if he wishes, he can give Tasleem between every two Rak'ahs, and that is better, as in the third type and others. Al-Hafiz Muhammad Ibn Nasr al-Marwazi, may Allah have mercy on him, said in "Qiyam al-Layl": "What we choose for one who prays at night in Ramadan and other times is to give Tasleem between every two Rak'ahs. Until if he wants to pray three Rak'ahs, he recites in the first Rak'ah 'Glorify the Name of your Lord, the Most High' (Al-A'la) and in the second 'Say, O Disbelievers' (Al-Kafirun), recites Tashahhud in the second and gives Tasleem. Then he stands and prays a Rak'ah reciting in it the Opening of the Book (Al-Fatiha) and 'Say, He is Allah, [who is] One' (Al-Ikhlas) and the two Mu'awwidhatayn." (Then he mentioned some of the previous types). Then he said: "And all of that is permissible to act upon, following his example, peace and blessings be upon him. However, the choice is what we mentioned, because the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, when asked about the night prayer, answered: 'The night prayer is two by two.' So we chose what he chose for his Ummah, and permitted the action of one who followed him and did like his action if no prohibition was narrated from him regarding that." Then he said: "Acting upon all these narrations is permissible according to us. They only differed because the prayer at night is voluntary: Witr and other than Witr. So he, peace and blessings be upon him, used to vary his prayer at night and his Witr as we mentioned: praying sometimes like this and sometimes like that. All of that is permissible and good. As for Witr with three Rak'ahs, we did not find [108] from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, an authentic, explicit report that he performed Witr with three without giving Tasleem except at their end, as we found regarding the five, seven, and nine. However, we found reports from him that he performed Witr with three without mention of Tasleem in them." Then he cited with his authentic chain from Ibn Abbas "that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to perform Witr with three, reciting 'Glorify the Name of your Lord, the Most High', 'Say, O Disbelievers', and 'Say, He is Allah, [who is] One'." Then he said: "And in the chapter are [reports] from Imran bin Husain, Aisha, Abdur Rahman bin Abza, and Anas bin Malik." He said: "These are ambiguous reports. It is possible that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, gave Tasleem in the two Rak'ahs of these three that were narrated he performed Witr with, because it is permissible to say of one who prayed ten Rak'ahs giving Tasleem between every two Rak'ahs: 'So-and-so prayed ten Rak'ahs.' And explicit reports that do not bear except one meaning [109] are more worthy to be followed and used as proof. However, we narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that he gave the one performing Witr the choice between performing Witr with five, or with three, or with one. And we narrated from some of the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, that they performed Witr with three not giving Tasleem except at their end. So acting upon that is permissible, and the choice is what we clarified." Then he said: "The matter according to us is that Witr with one, three, five, seven, and nine is all permissible and good, based on what we narrated of reports from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and his Companions after him. And what we choose is what we described before. If a man prays Isha and then wants to perform Witr after it with one Rak'ah without praying anything before it, what we choose for him and recommend is that he precedes it with two Rak'ahs or more, then performs Witr with one. If he does not do so and performs Witr with one, it is permissible. We have narrated from more than one of the elite Companions of Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, that they did that. Malik and others disliked that, but the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, are more worthy of being followed." Then he said: [110]

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: "And reports regarding the dislike of Witr with three have been narrated, some from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and some from the Companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and the Successors. Among them is" then he mentioned his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Do not perform Witr with three resembling the Maghrib prayer, but perform Witr with five..." Its chain is weak, but Al-Tahawi and others narrated it from another path with an authentic chain. It apparently contradicts the Hadith of Abu Ayyub extracted there with the wording "...and whoever wishes, let him perform Witr with three." The reconciliation between them is by interpreting the prohibition as applying to praying the three with two Tashahhuds, because in this form it resembles the Maghrib prayer. But if he does not sit except at its end, there is no resemblance. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar mentioned this meaning in "Al-Fath," and Al-San'ani deemed it good in "Subul al-Salam." The furthest from resembling Maghrib in Witr is separating with Tasleem between the Shafi' (even) and the Witr (odd), as is obvious. For this reason, Ibn al-Qayyim said in "Al-Zad" after mentioning the Hadith: "He did not use to give Tasleem in the two Rak'ahs of Witr": "This description is questionable. For Abu Hatim Ibn Hibban narrated in his Sahih from Abu Hurairah from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him: 'Do not perform Witr with three; perform Witr with five or seven, and do not resemble the Maghrib prayer.' Al-Daraqutni said: 'Its narrators are all trustworthy.' Mahna said: I asked Abu Abdullah (meaning Imam Ahmad): 'Which view do you hold regarding Witr? Do you give Tasleem in the two Rak'ahs?' He said: 'Yes.' I said: 'Why?' He said: 'Because the Hadiths regarding it are stronger and more numerous from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him and his family.' And Harith said: Ahmad was asked about Witr? He said: 'He gives Tasleem in the two Rak'ahs. And if he does not give Tasleem, I hope it does not harm him, except that Tasleem is more established from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him and his family.'" It is summarized from all the above that performing Witr with any of these preceding types is permissible and good, and that performing Witr with three with two Tashahhuds like the Maghrib prayer has no authentic explicit Hadith supporting it; rather, it is not free from dislike. Therefore, we choose not to sit between the Shafi' and the Witr, and if one sits, he should give Tasleem. This is better due to what preceded. And Allah is the Grantor of success; there is no Lord but He. [112]

text: 8 - Encouragement to Perfect the Prayer and Warning Against Performing it Badly: O noble reader, you are now in the month of fasting and night prayer, the blessed month of Ramadan. So you must be the example of a righteous believer - obedient to his Lord and following the Sunnah of his Prophet in everything he brought from his Lord, especially regarding the establishment of this great worship (Tarawih prayer). For he, peace and blessings be upon him, said regarding it: "Whoever stands (in prayer) in Ramadan out of faith and expecting reward, his previous sins will be forgiven." Narrated by the two Sheikhs and others. You have learned from what preceded in this treatise something good regarding the description of his prayer, peace and blessings be upon him, in the night prayer of Ramadan in terms of perfecting the prayer and prolonging it, such as the saying of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her: "...He prays four, so do not ask about their beauty and length. Then he prays four, so do not ask about their beauty and length." And her saying: "He remains in his prostration for the duration it takes one of you to read fifty verses." And the saying of Hudhayfah: "...Then he recited Al-Baqarah (meaning in the first Rak'ah), then he bowed, and his bowing was like his standing," then he mentioned the standing after bowing and the prostration similarly. You also learned that the Predecessors (Salaf) in the time of Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, used to prolong the recitation in Tarawih prayer, reciting about three hundred verses in it, so that [113]

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: they used to lean on staffs due to the length of standing, and they would not leave the prayer except with the break of dawn. This should be a motivator for all of us to approach in our Tarawih prayer their prayer to the extent of our ability. So let us reduce the recitation in it and increase the Tasbeeh and remembrance in bowing and prostration and what is between them until we feel even a little bit of Khushu' (humility/focus), which is the soul and core of prayer. This Khushu' has been lost by many of those praying this prayer due to their eagerness to perform it with the alleged number of twenty without care for tranquility in it. Rather, they peck it like the pecking of roosters, as if they are wheels and machines going up and down automatically. This does not enable them to ponder over what they hear of the words of Allah, Blessed and Exalted; rather, it is difficult for a person to follow them except with great difficulty. [114]

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: I say this knowing that not a few Imams of mosques have realized recently the poor performance Tarawih prayer has reached, so they returned to praying it as eleven Rak'ahs with some tranquility and Khushu'. May Allah increase their success in practicing the Sunnah and reviving it, and increase the likes of them in Damascus and elsewhere. [115]

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: Hadiths regarding the encouragement to perfect the performance of prayer and warning against performing it badly: To encourage these people to continue perfecting the prayer and increase in it, and to warn those who perform Tarawih and other prayers badly, I cite some authentic Hadiths narrated regarding the encouragement to perfect it and warning against performing it badly. I say: (Sahih) - 1 - From Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, that a man entered the mosque to pray while the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was in a corner of the mosque. He came and greeted him. He said to him: "[And upon you be peace.] Go back and pray, for you have not prayed." So he went back and prayed, then greeted him. He said: "And upon you [be peace]. Go back and pray, for you have not prayed." He said in the third time: "Teach me." He said: "When you stand for prayer, perfect the ablution, then face the Qiblah and say Takbeer, and recite what is easy for you of the Quran. Then bow until you are tranquil bowing, then raise your head until you are straight standing, then prostrate until you are tranquil prostrating, then rise until you sit straight and tranquil, then prostrate until you are tranquil prostrating, then rise until you are straight standing. Then do that in all your prayer." Narrated by Al-Bukhari, Muslim, and others. [116]

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Sahih) - 2 - From Abu Mas'ud Al-Badri who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The prayer of a man does not suffice until he straightens his back in bowing and prostration." Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, Al-Darimi, Al-Tahawi, Al-Tayalisi, Ahmad, and Al-Daraqutni, and he said: "Its chain is established authentic (Sahih)." And it is as he said, and Al-A'mash explicitly stated hearing it in the narration of Al-Tayalisi. (Sahih) - 3 - From Abu Hurairah that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The worst of people in theft is the one who steals from his prayer." They said: "O Messenger of Allah, how does he steal from his prayer?" He said: "He does not complete its bowing and prostration." Narrated by Al-Hakim who authenticated it, and Al-Dhahabi agreed. It has a witness with him from the Hadith of Abu Qatadah, another with Malik from Al-Nu'man bin Murrah (authentic Mursal chain), and a third with Al-Tayalisi from Abu Sa'id, authenticated by Al-Suyuti in "Tanwir al-Hawalik." [117]

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Hasan) - 4 - From the commanders of the armies: Amr bin Al-Aas, Khalid bin Al-Walid, Shurahbil bin Hasanah, and Yazid bin Abi Sufyan, they said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, saw a man not completing his bowing and pecking in his prostration while praying. He said: "If this one died in this state, he would die on other than the religion (Millah) of Muhammad. [He pecks his prayer as a crow pecks blood]. The example of the one who does not complete his bowing and pecks in his prostration is like the hungry man who eats one or two dates; they do not avail him anything." Narrated by Al-Ajurri in Al-Arba'in and Al-Bayhaqi with a Hasan chain. Al-Mundhiri said: Narrated by Al-Tabarani in Al-Kabir and Abu Ya'la with a Hasan chain, and Ibn Khuzaymah in his Sahih. (Sahih) - 5 - From Talq bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Allah does not look at the prayer of a servant who does not straighten his spine between its bowing and its prostration." Narrated by Ahmad, Al-Tabarani in "Al-Kabir," and Al-Diya' Al-Maqdisi in "Al-Mukhtara." Its chain is Sahih, and it has a witness in the Musnad, and its narrators are trustworthy. Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi authenticated it in "Takhrij Al-Ihya," and Al-Mundhiri said: "Its chain is good." [118]

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: (Sahih) - 6 - From Ammar bin Yasir, may Allah be pleased with him, who said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "A servant may pray a prayer and nothing is written for him of it except a tenth, a ninth, an eighth, a seventh, a sixth, a fifth, a quarter, a third, a half." Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad via two paths from him; Al-Hafiz Al-Iraqi authenticated one of them. Ibn Hibban also narrated it in his Sahih as in "Al-Targhib" (1/184). (Sahih) - 7 - From Abdullah bin Al-Shikhir who said: I came to the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, while he was praying, and his chest made a sound like the boiling of a pot, meaning he was weeping. Narrated by Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, Al-Bayhaqi, and Ahmad with a Sahih chain according to the conditions of Muslim. Also narrated by Ibn Khuzaymah and Ibn Hibban in their Sahihs as in "Sahih Al-Targhib wa Al-Tarhib" (No. 545). [119]

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: These noble Hadiths include by their generality and absoluteness all prayers, whether obligatory or voluntary, night or day. Scholars have pointed this out regarding Tarawih prayer. Al-Nawawi said in Al-Adhkar (4/297 with explanation by Ibn Allan) in the chapter on Adhkar of Tarawih prayer: "The description of the prayer itself is like the description of other prayers as previously explained. It includes all the aforementioned Adhkar, such as the opening supplication, completing the remaining Adhkar, completing the Tashahhud and the supplication after it, and other things mentioned previously. Although this is apparent and well-known, I drew attention to it due to the negligence of most people regarding it and their omission of most Adhkar, whereas the correct way is what preceded." Al-Amiri said in "Bahjat al-Mahafil wa Bughyat al-Amathil fi Talkhis al-Siyar wal-Mu'jizat wal-Shama'il" at the end of the book: "Among what must be attended to and warned against is what many Imams leading Tarawih are accustomed to: rushing through recitation, lightening the pillars (Rukn), and omitting Adhkar. Scholars have said: Its description is like the description of other prayers in conditions and other etiquettes and all Adhkar like the opening supplication, Adhkar of pillars, and supplication after Tashahhud, etc. Included in this is their seeking verses of mercy so they only bow upon them. Perhaps their seeking of that leads them to [120] missing two important matters from the etiquettes of prayer and recitation: lengthening the second Rak'ah over the first, and pausing at speech that is connected to each other. The cause of all this is neglecting Sunnahs and their fading due to lack of use, until the one practicing them becomes ignored by many people because of his opposition to what the great majority is upon, due to the corruption of time. The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'The Hour will not be established until good becomes evil (Munkar) and evil becomes good (Ma'ruf).' So adhere to the Sunnah; demand it of yourself and command it to those who obey you, you will be saved and safe and blessed. The great master Abu Ali Al-Fudayl bin Iyad, may Allah have mercy on him and be pleased with him and benefit [us] by him, said: 'Do not feel lonely on the paths of guidance due to the fewness of its people, and do not be deceived by the abundance of those perishing.'" [121]

text: Summary of the Treatise: The discussions of this treatise have extended beyond what we thought, but it was unavoidable because it is what the scientific method of investigation requires. Finally, we decided to present to the noble readers a summary of it so that it may be present in their minds, making it easy for them to comprehend and act upon, Allah willing. So I say: It is summarized as follows: That congregation in Tarawih prayer is a Sunnah and not an innovation (Bid'ah), because the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed it for several nights. His leaving it afterwards was only out of fear that anyone from his Ummah might think it obligatory if he persisted in it. This fear disappeared with the completion of the Sharia upon his death, peace and blessings be upon him. And that he, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed it as eleven Rak'ahs. And that the Hadith saying he prayed it as twenty is very weak. And that it is not permissible to increase beyond eleven Rak'ahs because increasing it implies canceling his action, peace and blessings be upon him, and disabling his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "Pray as you have seen me pray." Therefore, it is not permissible to increase upon the Sunnah of Fajr and others [122]

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And we do not accuse of innovation (Tabdi') nor declare astray those who pray it with more than this number if the Sunnah was not clear to them and they did not follow desires. And that if it were said that increasing upon it is permissible, there is no doubt that stopping at it is better due to his saying, peace and blessings be upon him: "The best guidance is the guidance of Muhammad." And that Umar, may Allah be pleased with him, did not innovate anything in Tarawih prayer; rather, he revived the Sunnah of congregation in it and maintained the Sunnah number in it. And that what was narrated about him increasing it until he made it twenty Rak'ahs - none of its chains are authentic, and these chains are of the type that do not strengthen each other. Al-Shafi'i and Al-Tirmidhi pointed to weakening it, and Al-Nawawi, Al-Zayla'i, and others weakened some of them. And that the mentioned increase, even if proven, implies no obligation to act upon it today because it was for a cause that has ceased. Insisting on it has led its practitioners mostly to rushing the prayer and removing its Khushu' (focus) and even its validity at times. That our not adopting the increase is like the Sharia court judges not adopting Umar's opinion on enacting the triple divorce as three, and there is no difference; rather, our position is worthier than theirs even in the view of the blind followers (Muqallidin). [123]

publisher: Al-Ma'arif Library for Publishing and Distribution - Riyadh
text: And that it was not proven from any of the Companions that they prayed it as twenty Rak'ahs; rather, Al-Tirmidhi indicated the weakness of that regarding Ali. And that there is no consensus (Ijma') on this number. And that adhering to the Sunnah number is obligatory because it is what is established from him, peace and blessings be upon him, and from Umar. And we have been commanded to follow his Sunnah, peace and blessings be upon him, and the Sunnah of the Righteous Caliphs. And that the increase upon it was denied by Malik, Ibn al-Arabi, and other scholars. And that denying this increase does not necessitate denying the Mujtahid Imams who adopted it, just as disagreeing with them does not necessitate attacking their knowledge or preferring the dissenter over them in knowledge and understanding. And that although increasing upon eleven Rak'ahs is not permissible, less than it is permissible, even restricting to one Rak'ah from it, due to that being proven in the Sunnah and the Predecessors did it. And that the methods by which the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, prayed Witr are all permissible, and the best of them is the most numerous, and giving Tasleem between every two Rak'ahs. [124]
